[[Image:Zeus contra Poryphion Pergamonaltar.JPG|thumb|right|380px|Zeus contra Porphyrion (right), [[Pergamonmuseum]] Berlin.]] In [[Greek mythology]], '''Porphyrion''' was a [[Giants (Greek mythology)|giant]], one of the sons of [[Tartarus]] and [[Gaia (mythology)|Gaea]]. Referred to by [[Pindar]] as king of the Giants.<ref>Pindar, ''Pythian'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0162:book=P.:poem=8&highlight=porphyrion 8].</ref> After the [[Olympian gods]] imprisoned the [[Titan (mythology)|Titan]]s in [[Tartarus]], Porphyrion was one of twenty-four<ref>''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' of [[Pseudo-Apollodorus]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0022%3Atext%3DLibrary%3Abook%3D1%3Achapter%3D6%3Asection%3D1 1.6.1], also cited in [[Robert Graves|Graves']] ''[[The Greek Myths]]'', 35.a.</ref> [[anguiped]]e giants who made war on Olympus. During the Giant's revolt on Olympus, Porphyrion attempted to strangle [[Hera]]. An arrow from the bow of [[Eros]] inspired Porphyrion with lust for [[Hera]], and he tore her robes and would have [[rape|forced]] her, but an enraged Zeus shot him with a thunderbolt. The giant sprang back up from this attack, but [[Heracles]] mortally wounded him with an arrow."<ref>''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' of [[Pseudo-Apollodorus]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0022%3Atext%3DLibrary%3Abook%3D1%3Achapter%3D6%3Asection%3D1 1.6.2]. Translation by [[James George Frazer]].</ref> According to one source,<ref>http://www.maicar.com/GML/Dionysus2.html</ref>{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} when Hera set the Giant army against [[Dionysus]], Porphyrion was one of those. Hera promised him [[Hebe (mythology)|Hebe]]'s hand in marriage if he would defeat the Giant. ==See also== * [[Greek mythology in popular culture]] ==References== <references/> [[Category:Gigantes]] Read Rick Riordans book for more details
